solution.text:
Lets say that \(-(_{k}_)^{-2} \) is divided by y to give \( \frac {1}{4 \times {(_{k}_)}^{2}} \)
Hence, \( \frac {-(_{k}_)^{-2}}{y} = \frac {1}{4 \times (_{k}_)^{2}} \)
\( \Rightarrow \frac {-1}{_{k}_^{2} \times y} = \frac {1}{4 \times (_{k}_)^{2}} \)
Multiplying both sides by \( (_{k}_)^{2} \) we get,
\( \Rightarrow \frac {-1}{y} = \frac {1}{4} \)
\( \Rightarrow y=-4 \)

content.text: By what number should \( -(_{k}_)^{-2} \) be divided to get \( \frac {1}{4 \times {(_{k}_)}^{2}} \) ?
